Index (S) » Numo » GSL » Sf

Module: Numo::GSL::Sf

Defined in:
ext/numo/gsl/sf/gsl_sf.c

Defined Under Namespace

Modules: Legendre Classes: MathieuWorkspace

Class Method Summary collapse

  • .airy_Ai(x, [mode]) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Airy function Ai(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • .airy_Ai_deriv(x, [mode]) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Airy function derivative Ai'(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • .airy_Ai_deriv_e(x, [mode]) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Airy function derivative Ai'(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • .airy_Ai_deriv_scaled(x, [mode]) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled Airy function derivative S_A(x) Ai'(x).
  • .airy_Ai_deriv_scaled_e(x, [mode]) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled Airy function derivative S_A(x) Ai'(x).
  • .airy_Ai_e(x, [mode]) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Airy function Ai(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • .airy_Ai_scaled(x, [mode]) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute a scaled version of the Airy function S_A(x) Ai(x).
  • .airy_Ai_scaled_e(x, [mode]) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute a scaled version of the Airy function S_A(x) Ai(x).
  • .airy_Bi(x, [mode]) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Airy function Bi(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • .airy_Bi_deriv(x, [mode]) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Airy function derivative Bi'(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • .airy_Bi_deriv_e(x, [mode]) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Airy function derivative Bi'(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • .airy_Bi_deriv_scaled(x, [mode]) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled Airy function derivative S_B(x) Bi'(x).
  • .airy_Bi_deriv_scaled_e(x, [mode]) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled Airy function derivative S_B(x) Bi'(x).
  • .airy_Bi_e(x, [mode]) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Airy function Bi(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • .airy_Bi_scaled(x, [mode]) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute a scaled version of the Airy function S_B(x) Bi(x).
  • .airy_Bi_scaled_e(x, [mode]) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute a scaled version of the Airy function S_B(x) Bi(x).
  • .airy_zero_Ai(s) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function Ai(x).
  • .airy_zero_Ai_deriv(s) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function derivative Ai'(x).
  • .airy_zero_Ai_deriv_e(s) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function derivative Ai'(x).
  • .airy_zero_Ai_e(s) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function Ai(x).
  • .airy_zero_Bi(s) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function Bi(x).
  • .airy_zero_Bi_deriv(s) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function derivative Bi'(x).
  • .airy_zero_Bi_deriv_e(s) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function derivative Bi'(x).
  • .airy_zero_Bi_e(s) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function Bi(x).
  • .angle_restrict_pos(theta) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines force the angle theta to lie in the range [0, 2pi).
  • .angle_restrict_symm(theta) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines force the angle theta to lie in the range (-pi,pi].
  • .atanint(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Arctangent integral, which is defined as $hboxAtanInt(x) = int_0^x dt arctan(t)/t$ AtanInt(x) = int_0^x dt arctan(t)/t.
  • .atanint_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Arctangent integral, which is defined as $hboxAtanInt(x) = int_0^x dt arctan(t)/t$ AtanInt(x) = int_0^x dt arctan(t)/t.
  • .bessel_I0(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, I_0(x).
  • .bessel_I0_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, I_0(x).
  • .bessel_I0_scaled(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order exp(-|x|) I_0(x).
  • .bessel_i0_scaled(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, exp(-|x|) i_0(x).
  • .bessel_I0_scaled_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order exp(-|x|) I_0(x).
  • .bessel_i0_scaled_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, exp(-|x|) i_0(x).
  • .bessel_I1(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order, I_1(x).
  • .bessel_I1_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order, I_1(x).
  • .bessel_I1_scaled(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order exp(-|x|) I_1(x).
  • .bessel_i1_scaled(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of first order, exp(-|x|) i_1(x).
  • .bessel_I1_scaled_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order exp(-|x|) I_1(x).
  • .bessel_i1_scaled_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of first order, exp(-|x|) i_1(x).
  • .bessel_i2_scaled(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of second order, exp(-|x|) i_2(x) Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW.
  • .bessel_i2_scaled_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of second order, exp(-|x|) i_2(x) Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW.
  • .bessel_il_scaled(l, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of order l, exp(-|x|) i_l(x) Domain: l >= 0 Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EUNDRFLW.
  • .bessel_il_scaled_array(lmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This routine computes the values of the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel functions exp(-|x|) i_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .bessel_il_scaled_e(l, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of order l, exp(-|x|) i_l(x) Domain: l >= 0 Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EUNDRFLW.
  • .bessel_In(n, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, I_n(x).
  • .bessel_In_array(nmin, nmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This routine computes the values of the regular modified cylindrical Bessel functions I_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .bessel_In_e(n, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, I_n(x).
  • .bessel_In_scaled(n, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, exp(-|x|) I_n(x) Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW.
  • .bessel_In_scaled_array(nmin, nmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This routine computes the values of the scaled regular cylindrical Bessel functions exp(-|x|) I_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .bessel_In_scaled_e(n, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, exp(-|x|) I_n(x) Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW.
  • .bessel_Inu(nu, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the regular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, I_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • .bessel_Inu_e(nu, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the regular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, I_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • .bessel_Inu_scaled(nu, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, exp(-|x|)I_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • .bessel_Inu_scaled_e(nu, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, exp(-|x|)I_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • .bessel_J0(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, J_0(x).
  • .bessel_j0(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, j_0(x) = sin(x)/x.
  • .bessel_J0_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, J_0(x).
  • .bessel_j0_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, j_0(x) = sin(x)/x.
  • .bessel_J1(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of first order, J_1(x).
  • .bessel_j1(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of first order, j_1(x) = (sin(x)/x - cos(x))/x.
  • .bessel_J1_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of first order, J_1(x).
  • .bessel_j1_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of first order, j_1(x) = (sin(x)/x - cos(x))/x.
  • .bessel_j2(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of second order, j_2(x) = ((3/x^2 - 1)sin(x) - 3cos(x)/x)/x.
  • .bessel_j2_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of second order, j_2(x) = ((3/x^2 - 1)sin(x) - 3cos(x)/x)/x.
  • .bessel_jl(l, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of order l, j_l(x), for $l geq 0$ l >= 0 and $x geq 0$ x >= 0.
  • .bessel_jl_array(lmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This routine computes the values of the regular spherical Bessel functions j_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0 and $x geq 0$ x >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .bessel_jl_e(l, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of order l, j_l(x), for $l geq 0$ l >= 0 and $x geq 0$ x >= 0.
  • .bessel_jl_steed_array(lmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This routine uses Steed's method to compute the values of the regular spherical Bessel functions j_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0 and $x geq 0$ x >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .bessel_Jn(n, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of order n, J_n(x).
  • .bessel_Jn_array(nmin, nmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This routine computes the values of the regular cylindrical Bessel functions J_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .bessel_Jn_e(n, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of order n, J_n(x).
  • .bessel_Jnu(nu, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of fractional order nu, J_nu(x).
  • .bessel_Jnu_e(nu, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of fractional order nu, J_nu(x).
  • .bessel_K0(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, K_0(x), for x > 0.
  • .bessel_K0_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, K_0(x), for x > 0.
  • .bessel_K0_scaled(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order exp(x) K_0(x) for x>0.
  • .bessel_k0_scaled(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, exp(x) k_0(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_K0_scaled_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order exp(x) K_0(x) for x>0.
  • .bessel_k0_scaled_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, exp(x) k_0(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_K1(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order, K_1(x), for x > 0.
  • .bessel_K1_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order, K_1(x), for x > 0.
  • .bessel_K1_scaled(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order exp(x) K_1(x) for x>0.
  • .bessel_k1_scaled(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of first order, exp(x) k_1(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_K1_scaled_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order exp(x) K_1(x) for x>0.
  • .bessel_k1_scaled_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of first order, exp(x) k_1(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_k2_scaled(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of second order, exp(x) k_2(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_k2_scaled_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of second order, exp(x) k_2(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_kl_scaled(l, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of order l, exp(x) k_l(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_kl_scaled_array(lmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This routine computes the values of the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel functions exp(x) k_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0 and x>0, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .bessel_kl_scaled_e(l, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of order l, exp(x) k_l(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_Kn(n, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, K_n(x), for x > 0.
  • .bessel_Kn_array(nmin, nmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This routine computes the values of the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel functions K_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .bessel_Kn_e(n, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, K_n(x), for x > 0.
  • .bessel_Kn_scaled(n, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, exp(x) K_n(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_Kn_scaled_array(nmin, nmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This routine computes the values of the scaled irregular cylindrical Bessel functions exp(x) K_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .bessel_Kn_scaled_e(n, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, exp(x) K_n(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_Knu(nu, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the irregular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, K_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • .bessel_Knu_e(nu, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the irregular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, K_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • .bessel_Knu_scaled(nu, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, exp(+|x|) K_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • .bessel_Knu_scaled_e(nu, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, exp(+|x|) K_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • .bessel_lnKnu(nu, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the logarithm of the irregular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, ln(K_nu(x)) for x>0, nu>0.
  • .bessel_lnKnu_e(nu, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the logarithm of the irregular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, ln(K_nu(x)) for x>0, nu>0.
  • .bessel_Y0(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, Y_0(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_y0(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, y_0(x) = -cos(x)/x.
  • .bessel_Y0_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, Y_0(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_y0_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, y_0(x) = -cos(x)/x.
  • .bessel_Y1(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of first order, Y_1(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_y1(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of first order, y_1(x) = -(cos(x)/x + sin(x))/x.
  • .bessel_Y1_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of first order, Y_1(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_y1_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of first order, y_1(x) = -(cos(x)/x + sin(x))/x.
  • .bessel_y2(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of second order, y_2(x) = (-3/x^3 + 1/x)cos(x) - (3/x^2)sin(x).
  • .bessel_y2_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of second order, y_2(x) = (-3/x^3 + 1/x)cos(x) - (3/x^2)sin(x).
  • .bessel_yl(l, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of order l, y_l(x), for $l geq 0$ l >= 0.
  • .bessel_yl_array(lmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This routine computes the values of the irregular spherical Bessel functions y_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .bessel_yl_e(l, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of order l, y_l(x), for $l geq 0$ l >= 0.
  • .bessel_Yn(n, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of order n, Y_n(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_Yn_array(nmin, nmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This routine computes the values of the irregular cylindrical Bessel functions Y_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .bessel_Yn_e(n, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of order n, Y_n(x), for x>0.
  • .bessel_Ynu(nu, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of fractional order nu, Y_nu(x).
  • .bessel_Ynu_e(nu, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of fractional order nu, Y_nu(x).
  • .bessel_zero_J0(s) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the location of the s-th positive zero of the Bessel function J_0(x).
  • .bessel_zero_J0_e(s) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the location of the s-th positive zero of the Bessel function J_0(x).
  • .bessel_zero_J1(s) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the location of the s-th positive zero of the Bessel function J_1(x).
  • .bessel_zero_J1_e(s) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the location of the s-th positive zero of the Bessel function J_1(x).
  • .bessel_zero_Jnu(nu, s) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the location of the s-th positive zero of the Bessel function J_nu(x).
  • .bessel_zero_Jnu_e(nu, s) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the location of the s-th positive zero of the Bessel function J_nu(x).
  • .beta(a, b) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Beta Function, B(a,b) = Gamma(a)Gamma(b)/Gamma(a+b) subject to a and b not being negative integers.
  • .beta_e(a, b) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Beta Function, B(a,b) = Gamma(a)Gamma(b)/Gamma(a+b) subject to a and b not being negative integers.
  • .beta_inc(a, b, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the normalized incomplete Beta function I_x(a,b)=B_x(a,b)/B(a,b) where $B_x(a,b) = int_0^x t^a-1 (1-t)^b-1 dt$ B_x(a,b) = int_0^x t^@a-1@ (1-t)^@b-1@ dt for $0 le x le 1$ 0 <= x <= 1.
  • .beta_inc_e(a, b, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the normalized incomplete Beta function I_x(a,b)=B_x(a,b)/B(a,b) where $B_x(a,b) = int_0^x t^a-1 (1-t)^b-1 dt$ B_x(a,b) = int_0^x t^@a-1@ (1-t)^@b-1@ dt for $0 le x le 1$ 0 <= x <= 1.
  • .Chi(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the integral $hboxSf.Chi(x) := Re[ gamma_E + log(x) + int_0^x dt (cosh(t)-1)/t]$ Chi(x) := Re[ gamma_E + log(x) + int_0^x dt (cosh(t)-1)/t] , where gamma_E is the Euler constant (available as the macro M_EULER).
  • .Chi_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the integral $hboxSf.Chi(x) := Re[ gamma_E + log(x) + int_0^x dt (cosh(t)-1)/t]$ Chi(x) := Re[ gamma_E + log(x) + int_0^x dt (cosh(t)-1)/t] , where gamma_E is the Euler constant (available as the macro M_EULER).
  • .choose(n, m) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the combinatorial factor n choose m = n!/(m!(n-m)!) exceptions: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW.
  • .choose_e(n, m) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the combinatorial factor n choose m = n!/(m!(n-m)!) exceptions: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW.
  • .Ci(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Cosine integral $hboxSf.Ci(x) = -int_x^infty dt cos(t)/t$ Ci(x) = -int_x^infty dt cos(t)/t for x > 0.
  • .Ci_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Cosine integral $hboxSf.Ci(x) = -int_x^infty dt cos(t)/t$ Ci(x) = -int_x^infty dt cos(t)/t for x > 0.
  • .clausen(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Clausen integral Cl_2(x).
  • .clausen_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Clausen integral Cl_2(x).
  • .complex_cos_e(zr, zi) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function computes the complex cosine, cos(z_r + i z_i) storing the real and imaginary parts in czr, czi.
  • .complex_dilog_e(r, theta) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function computes the full complex-valued dilogarithm for the complex argument z = r exp(i theta).
  • .complex_log_e(zr, zi) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This routine computes the complex logarithm of z = z_r + i z_i.
  • .complex_logsin_e(zr, zi) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function computes the logarithm of the complex sine, log(sin(z_r + i z_i)) storing the real and imaginary parts in lszr, lszi.
  • .complex_sin_e(zr, zi) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function computes the complex sine, sin(z_r + i z_i) storing the real and imaginary parts in szr, szi.
  • .conicalP_0(lambda, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the conical function $P^0_+ i lambda(x)$ P^0_@+ i lambda@(x) for x > -1.
  • .conicalP_0_e(lambda, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the conical function $P^1_+ i lambda(x)$ P^1_@+ i lambda@(x) for x > -1.

  • .conicalP_cyl_reg(m, lambda, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

  • .conicalP_cyl_reg_e(m, lambda, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Regular Cylindrical Conical Function $P^-m_+ i lambda(x)$ P^@-m@_@+ i lambda@(x) for x > -1, $m ge -1$ m >= -1.
  • .conicalP_half(lambda, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

  • .conicalP_mhalf(lambda, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the regular Spherical Conical Function $P^-1/2_+ i lambda(x)$ P^@-1/2@_@+ i lambda@(x) for x > -1.
  • .conicalP_mhalf_e(lambda, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

  • .coulomb_CL_array(Lmin, kmax, eta) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function computes the Coulomb wave function normalization constant C_L(eta) for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax, Lmin > -1.
  • .coulomb_CL_e(L, eta) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function computes the Coulomb wave function normalization constant C_L(eta) for L > -1.
  • .coulomb_wave_F_array(L_min, kmax, eta, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function computes the Coulomb wave function F_L(eta,x) for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax, storing the results in fc_array.
  • .coulomb_wave_FG_array(L_min, kmax, eta, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function computes the functions F_L(eta,x), G_L(eta,x) for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax storing the results in fc_array and gc_array.
  • .coulomb_wave_FG_e(eta, x, L_F, k) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function computes the Coulomb wave functions F_L(eta,x), $G_L-k(eta,x)$ G_@L-k@(eta,x) and their derivatives F'_L(eta,x), $G'_L-k(eta,x)$ G'_@L-k@(eta,x) with respect to x.
  • .coulomb_wave_FGp_array(L_min, kmax, eta, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function computes the functions F_L(eta,x), G_L(eta,x) and their derivatives F'_L(eta,x), G'_L(eta,x) for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax storing the results in fc_array, gc_array, fcp_array and gcp_array.
  • .coulomb_wave_sphF_array(L_min, kmax, eta, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function computes the Coulomb wave function divided by the argument F_L(eta, x)/x for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax, storing the results in fc_array.

  • .debye_1(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the first-order Debye function D_1(x) = (1/x) int_0^x dt (t/(e^t - 1)).

    These routines compute the first-order Debye function D_1(x) = (1/x) int_0^x dt (t/(e^t - 1)).
  • .debye_2(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the second-order Debye function D_2(x) = (2/x^2) int_0^x dt (t^2/(e^t - 1)).
  • .debye_2_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the second-order Debye function D_2(x) = (2/x^2) int_0^x dt (t^2/(e^t - 1)).

  • .erf(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the error function $erf(x)$ erf(x), where $erf(x) = (2/sqrtpi) int_0^x dt exp(-t^2)$ erf(x) = (2/sqrt(pi)) int_0^x dt exp(-t^2).
  • .erf_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

  • .erf_Q(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the upper tail of the Gaussian probability function $Q(x) = (1/sqrt2pi) int_x^infty dt exp(-t^2/2)$ Q(x) = (1/sqrt@2pi@) int_x^infty dt exp(-t^2/2).
  • .erf_Q_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the upper tail of the Gaussian probability function $Q(x) = (1/sqrt2pi) int_x^infty dt exp(-t^2/2)$ Q(x) = (1/sqrt@2pi@) int_x^infty dt exp(-t^2/2).
  • .erf_Z(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Gaussian probability density function $Z(x) = (1/sqrt2pi) exp(-x^2/2)$ Z(x) = (1/sqrt@2pi@) exp(-x^2/2).
  • .erf_Z_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Gaussian probability density function $Z(x) = (1/sqrt2pi) exp(-x^2/2)$ Z(x) = (1/sqrt@2pi@) exp(-x^2/2).
  • .erfc(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the complementary error function $erfc(x) = 1 - erf(x) = (2/sqrtpi) int_x^infty exp(-t^2)$ erfc(x) = 1 - erf(x) = (2/sqrt(pi)) int_x^infty exp(-t^2).
  • .erfc_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the complementary error function $erfc(x) = 1 - erf(x) = (2/sqrtpi) int_x^infty exp(-t^2)$ erfc(x) = 1 - erf(x) = (2/sqrt(pi)) int_x^infty exp(-t^2).

  • .expint_E1_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

  • .expint_E2(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the second-order exponential integral E_2(x),.
  • .expint_E2_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the second-order exponential integral E_2(x),.
  • .expint_Ei(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the exponential integral $hboxEi(x)$ Ei(x),.
  • .expint_Ei_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the exponential integral $hboxEi(x)$ Ei(x),.
  • .expint_En(n, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the exponential integral E_n(x) of order n,.
  • .expint_En_e(n, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the exponential integral E_n(x) of order n,.
  • .expm1(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the quantity exp(x)-1 using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • .expm1_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the quantity exp(x)-1 using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • .exprel(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the quantity (exp(x)-1)/x using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • .exprel_2(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the quantity 2(exp(x)-1-x)/x^2 using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • .exprel_2_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the quantity 2(exp(x)-1-x)/x^2 using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • .exprel_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the quantity (exp(x)-1)/x using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • .exprel_n(n, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the N-relative exponential, which is the n-th generalization of the functions gsl_sf_exprel and gsl_sf_exprel_2.
  • .exprel_n_e(n, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the N-relative exponential, which is the n-th generalization of the functions gsl_sf_exprel and gsl_sf_exprel_2.
  • .fact(n) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the factorial n!.
  • .fact_e(n) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the factorial n!.
  • .fermi_dirac_0(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of 0.
  • .fermi_dirac_0_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of 0.
  • .fermi_dirac_1(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of 1, F_1(x) = int_0^infty dt (t /(exp(t-x)+1)).
  • .fermi_dirac_1_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of 1, F_1(x) = int_0^infty dt (t /(exp(t-x)+1)).
  • .fermi_dirac_2(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of 2, F_2(x) = (1/2) int_0^infty dt (t^2 /(exp(t-x)+1)).
  • .fermi_dirac_2_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of 2, F_2(x) = (1/2) int_0^infty dt (t^2 /(exp(t-x)+1)).
  • .fermi_dirac_3half(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral $F_3/2(x)$ F_@3/2@(x).
  • .fermi_dirac_3half_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral $F_3/2(x)$ F_@3/2@(x).
  • .fermi_dirac_half(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral $F_1/2(x)$ F_@1/2@(x).
  • .fermi_dirac_half_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral $F_1/2(x)$ F_@1/2@(x).
  • .fermi_dirac_inc_0(x, b) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the incomplete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of zero, $F_0(x,b) = ln(1 + e^b-x) - (b-x)$ F_0(x,b) = ln(1 + e^@b-x@) - (b-x).
  • .fermi_dirac_inc_0_e(x, b) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the incomplete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of zero, $F_0(x,b) = ln(1 + e^b-x) - (b-x)$ F_0(x,b) = ln(1 + e^@b-x@) - (b-x).
  • .fermi_dirac_int(j, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an integer index of j, F_j(x) = (1/Gamma(j+1)) int_0^infty dt (t^j /(exp(t-x)+1)).
  • .fermi_dirac_int_e(j, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an integer index of j, F_j(x) = (1/Gamma(j+1)) int_0^infty dt (t^j /(exp(t-x)+1)).
  • .fermi_dirac_m1(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of -1.
  • .fermi_dirac_m1_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of -1.
  • .fermi_dirac_mhalf(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral $F_-1/2(x)$ F_@-1/2@(x).
  • .fermi_dirac_mhalf_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral $F_-1/2(x)$ F_@-1/2@(x).
  • .gamma(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Gamma function Gamma(x), subject to x not being a negative integer or zero.
  • .gamma_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Gamma function Gamma(x), subject to x not being a negative integer or zero.
  • .gamma_inc(a, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These functions compute the unnormalized incomplete Gamma Function $Gamma(a,x) = int_x^infty dt, t^(a-1) exp(-t)$ Gamma(a,x) = int_x^infty dt t^@a-1@ exp(-t) for a real and $x ge 0$ x >= 0.
  • .gamma_inc_e(a, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These functions compute the unnormalized incomplete Gamma Function $Gamma(a,x) = int_x^infty dt, t^(a-1) exp(-t)$ Gamma(a,x) = int_x^infty dt t^@a-1@ exp(-t) for a real and $x ge 0$ x >= 0.
  • .gamma_inc_P(a, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the complementary normalized incomplete Gamma Function $P(a,x) = 1 - Q(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) int_0^x dt, t^(a-1) exp(-t)$ P(a,x) = 1 - Q(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) int_0^x dt t^@a-1@ exp(-t) for a > 0, $x ge 0$ x >= 0.
  • .gamma_inc_P_e(a, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the complementary normalized incomplete Gamma Function $P(a,x) = 1 - Q(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) int_0^x dt, t^(a-1) exp(-t)$ P(a,x) = 1 - Q(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) int_0^x dt t^@a-1@ exp(-t) for a > 0, $x ge 0$ x >= 0.
  • .gamma_inc_Q(a, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the normalized incomplete Gamma Function $Q(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) int_x^infty dt, t^(a-1) exp(-t)$ Q(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) int_x^infty dt t^@a-1@ exp(-t) for a > 0, $x ge 0$ x >= 0.
  • .gamma_inc_Q_e(a, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the normalized incomplete Gamma Function $Q(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) int_x^infty dt, t^(a-1) exp(-t)$ Q(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) int_x^infty dt t^@a-1@ exp(-t) for a > 0, $x ge 0$ x >= 0.
  • .gammainv(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the reciprocal of the gamma function, 1/Gamma(x) using the real Lanczos method.
  • .gammainv_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the reciprocal of the gamma function, 1/Gamma(x) using the real Lanczos method.
  • .gammastar(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the regulated Gamma Function Gamma^*(x) for x > 0.
  • .gammastar_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the regulated Gamma Function Gamma^*(x) for x > 0.
  • .gegenpoly_1(lambda, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These functions evaluate the Gegenbauer polynomials $C^(lambda)_n(x)$ C^@(lambda)@_n(x) using explicit representations for n =1, 2, 3.

  • .gegenpoly_3_e(lambda, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

  • .gegenpoly_array(nmax, lambda, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

  • .gegenpoly_n(n, lambda, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

  • .legendre_array(norm, lmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These functions calculate all normalized associated Legendre polynomials for 0 le l le lmax and 0 le m le l for $|x| le 1$ |x| <= 1.
  • .legendre_array_e(norm, lmax, x, csphase) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These functions calculate all normalized associated Legendre polynomials for 0 le l le lmax and 0 le m le l for $|x| le 1$ |x| <= 1.
  • .legendre_array_index(l, m) ⇒ Numo::UInt64

    This function returns the index into result_array, result_deriv_array, or result_deriv2_array corresponding to P_l^m(x), P_l^'m(x), or P_l^''m(x).
  • .legendre_array_n(lmax) ⇒ Numo::UInt64

    This function returns the minimum array size for maximum degree lmax needed for the array versions of the associated Legendre functions.
  • .legendre_deriv2_alt_array(norm, lmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These functions calculate all normalized associated Legendre functions and their (alternate) first and second derivatives up to degree lmax for $|x| < 1$ |x| < 1.
  • .legendre_deriv2_alt_array_e(norm, lmax, x, csphase) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These functions calculate all normalized associated Legendre functions and their (alternate) first and second derivatives up to degree lmax for $|x| < 1$ |x| < 1.

    These functions calculate all normalized associated Legendre functions and their first and second derivatives up to degree lmax for $|x| < 1$ |x| < 1.
  • .legendre_deriv2_array_e(norm, lmax, x, csphase) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

  • .legendre_deriv_alt_array(norm, lmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These functions calculate all normalized associated Legendre functions and their (alternate) first derivatives up to degree lmax for $|x| < 1$ |x| < 1.
  • .legendre_deriv_alt_array_e(norm, lmax, x, csphase) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These functions calculate all normalized associated Legendre functions and their (alternate) first derivatives up to degree lmax for $|x| < 1$ |x| < 1.
  • .legendre_deriv_array(norm, lmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These functions calculate all normalized associated Legendre functions and their first derivatives up to degree lmax for $|x| < 1$ |x| < 1.
  • .legendre_deriv_array_e(norm, lmax, x, csphase) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These functions calculate all normalized associated Legendre functions and their first derivatives up to degree lmax for $|x| < 1$ |x| < 1.
  • .legendre_H3d(l, lambda, eta) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the l-th radial eigenfunction of the Laplacian on the 3-dimensional hyperbolic space $eta ge 0$ eta >= 0, $l ge 0$ l >= 0.
  • .legendre_H3d_0(lambda, eta) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the zeroth radial eigenfunction of the Laplacian on the 3-dimensional hyperbolic space, $$L^H3d_0(lambda,eta) := over lambdasinh(eta)$$ L^@H3d@_0(lambda,eta) := sin(lambdaeta)/(lambdasinh(eta)) for $eta ge 0$ eta >= 0.
  • .legendre_H3d_0_e(lambda, eta) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the zeroth radial eigenfunction of the Laplacian on the 3-dimensional hyperbolic space, $$L^H3d_0(lambda,eta) := over lambdasinh(eta)$$ L^@H3d@_0(lambda,eta) := sin(lambdaeta)/(lambdasinh(eta)) for $eta ge 0$ eta >= 0.
  • .legendre_H3d_1(lambda, eta) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the first radial eigenfunction of the Laplacian on the 3-dimensional hyperbolic space, $$L^H3d_1(lambda,eta) := + 1} eta)over lambda sinh(eta)right) left(coth(eta) - lambda cot(lambdaeta)right)$$ L^@H3d@_1(lambda,eta) := 1/sqrt@+ 1@ sin(lambda eta)/(lambda sinh(eta)) (coth(eta) - lambda cot(lambdaeta)) for $eta ge 0$ eta >= 0.
  • .legendre_H3d_1_e(lambda, eta) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the first radial eigenfunction of the Laplacian on the 3-dimensional hyperbolic space, $$L^H3d_1(lambda,eta) := + 1} eta)over lambda sinh(eta)right) left(coth(eta) - lambda cot(lambdaeta)right)$$ L^@H3d@_1(lambda,eta) := 1/sqrt@+ 1@ sin(lambda eta)/(lambda sinh(eta)) (coth(eta) - lambda cot(lambdaeta)) for $eta ge 0$ eta >= 0.
  • .legendre_H3d_array(lmax, lambda, eta) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function computes an array of radial eigenfunctions $L^H3d_l( lambda, eta)$ L^@H3d@_l(lambda, eta) for $0 le l le lmax$ 0 <= l <= lmax.
  • .legendre_H3d_e(l, lambda, eta) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the l-th radial eigenfunction of the Laplacian on the 3-dimensional hyperbolic space $eta ge 0$ eta >= 0, $l ge 0$ l >= 0.
  • .legendre_P1(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These functions evaluate the Legendre polynomials $P_l(x)$ P_l(x) using explicit representations for l=1, 2, 3.
  • .legendre_P1_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These functions evaluate the Legendre polynomials $P_l(x)$ P_l(x) using explicit representations for l=1, 2, 3.
  • .legendre_P2(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These functions evaluate the Legendre polynomials $P_l(x)$ P_l(x) using explicit representations for l=1, 2, 3.
  • .legendre_P2_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These functions evaluate the Legendre polynomials $P_l(x)$ P_l(x) using explicit representations for l=1, 2, 3.
  • .legendre_P3(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These functions evaluate the Legendre polynomials $P_l(x)$ P_l(x) using explicit representations for l=1, 2, 3.
  • .legendre_P3_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These functions evaluate the Legendre polynomials $P_l(x)$ P_l(x) using explicit representations for l=1, 2, 3.
  • .legendre_Pl(l, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These functions evaluate the Legendre polynomial $P_l(x)$ P_l(x) for a specific value of l, x subject to $l ge 0$ l >= 0, $|x| le 1$ |x| <= 1 Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM.
  • .legendre_Pl_array(v0, v1) ⇒ Object

    These functions compute arrays of Legendre polynomials P_l(x) and derivatives dP_l(x)/dx, for l = 0, dots, lmax, $|x| le 1$ |x| <= 1 Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM @overload legendre_Pl_array(lmax,x).
  • .legendre_Pl_deriv_array(v0, v1) ⇒ Object

    These functions compute arrays of Legendre polynomials P_l(x) and derivatives dP_l(x)/dx, for l = 0, dots, lmax, $|x| le 1$ |x| <= 1 Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM @overload legendre_Pl_deriv_array(lmax,x).
  • .legendre_Pl_e(l, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These functions evaluate the Legendre polynomial $P_l(x)$ P_l(x) for a specific value of l, x subject to $l ge 0$ l >= 0, $|x| le 1$ |x| <= 1 Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM.
  • .legendre_Plm(l, m, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the associated Legendre polynomial P_l^m(x) for $m ge 0$ m >= 0, $l ge m$ l >= m, $|x| le 1$ |x| <= 1.
  • .legendre_Plm_e(l, m, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the associated Legendre polynomial P_l^m(x) for $m ge 0$ m >= 0, $l ge m$ l >= m, $|x| le 1$ |x| <= 1.
  • .legendre_Q0(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Legendre function Q_0(x) for x > -1, $x ne 1$ x != 1.
  • .legendre_Q0_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Legendre function Q_0(x) for x > -1, $x ne 1$ x != 1.
  • .legendre_Q1(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Legendre function Q_1(x) for x > -1, $x ne 1$ x != 1.
  • .legendre_Q1_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Legendre function Q_1(x) for x > -1, $x ne 1$ x != 1.
  • .legendre_Ql(l, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Legendre function Q_l(x) for x > -1, $x ne 1$ x != 1 and $l ge 0$ l >= 0.
  • .legendre_Ql_e(l, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Legendre function Q_l(x) for x > -1, $x ne 1$ x != 1 and $l ge 0$ l >= 0.
  • .legendre_sphPlm(l, m, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the normalized associated Legendre polynomial $sqrt(2l+1)/(4pi) sqrt(l-m)!/(l+m)! P_l^m(x)$ sqrt@(2l+1)/(4pi)@ sqrt@(l-m)!/(l+m)!@ P_l^m(x) suitable for use in spherical harmonics.
  • .legendre_sphPlm_e(l, m, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the normalized associated Legendre polynomial $sqrt(2l+1)/(4pi) sqrt(l-m)!/(l+m)! P_l^m(x)$ sqrt@(2l+1)/(4pi)@ sqrt@(l-m)!/(l+m)!@ P_l^m(x) suitable for use in spherical harmonics.
  • .lnbeta(a, b) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the logarithm of the Beta Function, log(B(a,b)) subject to a and b not being negative integers.
  • .lnbeta_e(a, b) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the logarithm of the Beta Function, log(B(a,b)) subject to a and b not being negative integers.

  • .lncosh(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute log(cosh(x)) for any x.
  • .lncosh_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute log(cosh(x)) for any x.
  • .lndoublefact(n) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the logarithm of the double factorial of n, log(n!!).
  • .lndoublefact_e(n) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the logarithm of the double factorial of n, log(n!!).
  • .lnfact(n) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the logarithm of the factorial of n, log(n!).
  • .lnfact_e(n) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the logarithm of the factorial of n, log(n!).
  • .lngamma(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the logarithm of the Gamma function, log(Gamma(x)), subject to x not being a negative integer or zero.
  • .lngamma_complex_e(zr, zi) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This routine computes log(Gamma(z)) for complex z=z_r+i z_i and z not a negative integer or zero, using the complex Lanczos method.
  • .lngamma_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the logarithm of the Gamma function, log(Gamma(x)), subject to x not being a negative integer or zero.
  • .lngamma_sgn_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This routine computes the sign of the gamma function and the logarithm of its magnitude, subject to x not being a negative integer or zero.
  • .lnpoch(a, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the logarithm of the Pochhammer symbol, log((a)_x) = log(Gamma(a + x)/Gamma(a)).
  • .lnpoch_e(a, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the logarithm of the Pochhammer symbol, log((a)_x) = log(Gamma(a + x)/Gamma(a)).
  • .lnpoch_sgn_e(a, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the sign of the Pochhammer symbol and the logarithm of its magnitude.
  • .lnsinh(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

  • .lnsinh_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute log(sinh(x)) for x > 0.
  • .log(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the logarithm of x, log(x), for x > 0.
  • .log_1plusx(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute log(1 + x) for x > -1 using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • .log_1plusx_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute log(1 + x) for x > -1 using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • .log_1plusx_mx(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute log(1 + x) - x for x > -1 using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • .log_1plusx_mx_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute log(1 + x) - x for x > -1 using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • .log_abs(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the logarithm of the magnitude of x, log(|x|), for x ne 0.
  • .log_abs_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the logarithm of the magnitude of x, log(|x|), for x ne 0.

    These routines compute the logarithm of x, log(x), for x > 0.

  • .mathieu_a(n, q) ⇒ Numo::Int32

    These routines compute the characteristic values a_n(q), b_n(q) of the Mathieu functions ce_n(q,x) and se_n(q,x), respectively.
  • .mathieu_a_array(order_min, order_max, q, work) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute a series of Mathieu characteristic values a_n(q), b_n(q) for n from order_min to order_max inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .mathieu_a_e(n, q) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the characteristic values a_n(q), b_n(q) of the Mathieu functions ce_n(q,x) and se_n(q,x), respectively.
  • .mathieu_b(n, q) ⇒ Numo::Int32

    These routines compute the characteristic values a_n(q), b_n(q) of the Mathieu functions ce_n(q,x) and se_n(q,x), respectively.
  • .mathieu_b_array(order_min, order_max, q, work) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute a series of Mathieu characteristic values a_n(q), b_n(q) for n from order_min to order_max inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .mathieu_b_e(n, q) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the characteristic values a_n(q), b_n(q) of the Mathieu functions ce_n(q,x) and se_n(q,x), respectively.
  • .mathieu_ce(n, q, x) ⇒ Numo::Int32

    These routines compute the angular Mathieu functions ce_n(q,x) and se_n(q,x), respectively.
  • .mathieu_ce_array(nmin, nmax, q, x, work) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute a series of the angular Mathieu functions ce_n(q,x) and se_n(q,x) of order n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .mathieu_ce_e(n, q, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the angular Mathieu functions ce_n(q,x) and se_n(q,x), respectively.
  • .mathieu_Mc(j, n, q, x) ⇒ Numo::Int32

    These routines compute the radial j-th kind Mathieu functions $Mc_n^(j)(q,x)$ Mc_n^@(j)@(q,x) and $Ms_n^(j)(q,x)$ Ms_n^@(j)@(q,x) of order n.
  • .mathieu_Mc_array(j, nmin, nmax, q, x, work) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute a series of the radial Mathieu functions of kind j, with order from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .mathieu_Mc_e(j, n, q, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the radial j-th kind Mathieu functions $Mc_n^(j)(q,x)$ Mc_n^@(j)@(q,x) and $Ms_n^(j)(q,x)$ Ms_n^@(j)@(q,x) of order n.
  • .mathieu_Ms(j, n, q, x) ⇒ Numo::Int32

    These routines compute the radial j-th kind Mathieu functions $Mc_n^(j)(q,x)$ Mc_n^@(j)@(q,x) and $Ms_n^(j)(q,x)$ Ms_n^@(j)@(q,x) of order n.
  • .mathieu_Ms_array(j, nmin, nmax, q, x, work) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute a series of the radial Mathieu functions of kind j, with order from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .mathieu_Ms_e(j, n, q, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

  • .mathieu_se(n, q, x) ⇒ Numo::Int32

    These routines compute the angular Mathieu functions ce_n(q,x) and se_n(q,x), respectively.
  • .mathieu_se_array(nmin, nmax, q, x, work) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute a series of the angular Mathieu functions ce_n(q,x) and se_n(q,x) of order n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • .mathieu_se_e(n, q, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the angular Mathieu functions ce_n(q,x) and se_n(q,x), respectively.
  • .multiply_e(x, y) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function multiplies x and y storing the product and its associated error in result.
  • .multiply_err_e(x, dx, y, dy) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function multiplies x and y with associated absolute errors dx and dy.
  • .poch(a, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Pochhammer symbol (a)_x = Gamma(a + x)/Gamma(a).
  • .poch_e(a, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Pochhammer symbol (a)_x = Gamma(a + x)/Gamma(a).
  • .pochrel(a, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the relative Pochhammer symbol ((a)_x - 1)/x where (a)_x = Gamma(a + x)/Gamma(a).
  • .pochrel_e(a, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the relative Pochhammer symbol ((a)_x - 1)/x where (a)_x = Gamma(a + x)/Gamma(a).
  • .polar_to_rect(r, theta) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function converts the polar coordinates (r,theta) to rectilinear coordinates (x,y), x = rcos(theta), y = rsin(theta).

    These routines compute the power x^n for integer n.
  • .pow_int_e(x, n) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the power x^n for integer n.
  • .psi(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Trigamma function psi'(x) for general x.

    These routines compute the Trigamma function psi'(n) for positive integer n.
  • .psi_1piy(y) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

  • .psi_1piy_e(y) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the real part of the digamma function on the line 1+i y, Re[psi(1 + i y)].

  • .psi_int(n) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

  • .psi_int_e(n) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the digamma function psi(n) for positive integer n.

  • .psi_n_e(n, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

  • .rect_to_polar(x, y) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    This function converts the rectilinear coordinates (x,y) to polar coordinates (r,theta), such that x = rcos(theta), y = rsin(theta).
  • .Shi(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

  • .sinc(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

  • .sinc_e(x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute sinc(x) = sin(pi x) / (pi x) for any value of x.
  • .synchrotron_1(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Riemann zeta function zeta(s) for arbitrary s, s ne 1.
  • .zeta_e(s) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Riemann zeta function zeta(s) for arbitrary s, s ne 1.
  • .zeta_int(n) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute the Riemann zeta function zeta(n) for integer n, n ne 1.
  • .zeta_int_e(n) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute the Riemann zeta function zeta(n) for integer n, n ne 1.
  • .zetam1(s) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute zeta(s) - 1 for arbitrary s, s ne 1.
  • .zetam1_e(s) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute zeta(s) - 1 for arbitrary s, s ne 1.
  • .zetam1_int(n) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

    These routines compute zeta(n) - 1 for integer n, n ne 1.
  • .zetam1_int_e(n) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

    These routines compute zeta(n) - 1 for integer n, n ne 1.

Class Method Details

.airy_Ai(x, [mode]) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

These routines compute the Airy function Ai(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.

Parameters:

  • x (Numo::DFloat)
  • mode (Integer) —

    The following precision levels are available: Numo::GSL::PREC_DOUBLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_SINGLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_APPROX.

.airy_Ai_deriv_scaled(x, [mode]) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

These routines compute the scaled Airy function derivative S_A(x) Ai'(x). For x>0 the scaling factor S_A(x) is $exp(+(2/3) x^3/2)$ exp(+(2/3) x^(3/2)), and is 1 for x<0.

Parameters:

  • x (Numo::DFloat)
  • mode (Integer) —

    The following precision levels are available: Numo::GSL::PREC_DOUBLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_SINGLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_APPROX.

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return

.airy_Bi_scaled(x, [mode]) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

These routines compute a scaled version of the Airy function S_B(x) Bi(x). For x>0 the scaling factor S_B(x) is $exp(-(2/3) x^3/2)$ exp(-(2/3) x^(3/2)), and is 1 for x<0.

Parameters:

  • x (Numo::DFloat)
  • mode (Integer) —

    The following precision levels are available: Numo::GSL::PREC_DOUBLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_SINGLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_APPROX.

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

.angle_restrict_pos(theta) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

These routines force the angle theta to lie in the range [0, 2pi).

Note that the mathematical value of 2pi is slightly greater than 2*M_PI, so the machine number 2*M_PI is included in the range.

Exceptional Return Values: GSL_ELOSS

Parameters:

  • theta (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return

.angle_restrict_symm(theta) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

These routines force the angle theta to lie in the range (-pi,pi].

Note that the mathematical value of pi is slightly greater than M_PI, so the machine numbers M_PI and -M_PI are included in the range. Exceptional Return Values: GSL_ELOSS

.bessel_il_scaled_array(lmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This routine computes the values of the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel functions exp(-|x|) i_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Domain: lmax >= 0 Conditions: l=0,1,…,lmax Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • lmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

6535

6541
6542
 
# File 'ext/numo/gsl/sf/gsl_sf.c', line 6510

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_il_scaled_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1)
{
  
    int c0;
  

  
    size_t shape[1];
  

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_il_scaled_array,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,1,2,ain,aout};

  
    void *opt;
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt = &c0; //lmax

  

      if (c0<0) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be lmax>=0");
    }
    shape[0] = c0+1;


  
#line 63 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v1);
  
}

.bessel_In_array(nmin, nmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This routine computes the values of the regular modified cylindrical Bessel functions I_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array. The start of the range nmin must be positive or zero. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Domain: nmin >=0, nmax >= nmin Conditions: n=nmin,…,nmax, nmin >=0, nmax >= nmin Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • nmin (Integer)
  • nmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]



3183
3184
3185

3190

3193
3194
3195
3196
3197
3198
3199
3200
3201
3202
3203
3204
3205
3206
3207
3208
3209
3210
3211
3212
3213

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_In_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2)
{
  
    int c0;
  
    int c1;
  

  
#line 42 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    size_t shape[1];
  

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_In_array,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,1,2,ain,aout};

  
#line 53 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    void *opt[2];
    
          c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //nmin

          c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //nmax

  

      if (c0<0 || c1<0 || c0>c1) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be nmin>=0 && nmax>=0 && nmin<=nmax");
    }
    shape[0] = c1-c0+1;


  
#line 63 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v2);

.bessel_In_scaled_array(nmin, nmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This routine computes the values of the scaled regular cylindrical Bessel functions exp(-|x|) I_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array. The start of the range nmin must be positive or zero. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Domain: nmin >=0, nmax >= nmin Conditions: n=nmin,…,nmax Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • nmin (Integer)
  • nmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

.bessel_jl_array(lmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This routine computes the values of the regular spherical Bessel functions j_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0 and $x geq 0$ x >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Domain: lmax >= 0 Conditions: l=0,1,…,lmax Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • lmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]



5242
5243
5244
5245
5246
5247
5248
5249
5250
5251
5252
5253
5254
5255
5256
5257
5258
5259
5260
5261
5262
5263
5264
5265
5266
5267
5268
5269
5270
5271
5272
5273
5274
 
# File 'ext/numo/gsl/sf/gsl_sf.c', line 5242

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_jl_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1)
{
  
    int c0;
  

  
    size_t shape[1];
  

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_jl_array,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,1,2,ain,aout};

  
    void *opt;
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt = &c0; //lmax

  

      if (c0<0) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be lmax>=0");
    }
    shape[0] = c0+1;


  
#line 63 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v1);
  
}

.bessel_jl_steed_array(lmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This routine uses Steed's method to compute the values of the regular spherical Bessel functions j_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0 and $x geq 0$ x >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array. The Steed/Barnett algorithm is described in Comp. Phys. Comm. 21, 297 (1981). Steed's method is more stable than the recurrence used in the other functions but is also slower. Domain: lmax >= 0 Conditions: l=0,1,…,lmax Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • lmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]



5331
5332
5333
5334
5335
5336
5337
5338
5339
5340
5341
5342
5343
5344
5345
5346
5347
5348
5349
5350
5351
5352
5353
5354
5355
5356
5357
5358
5359
5360
5361
5362
5363
 
# File 'ext/numo/gsl/sf/gsl_sf.c', line 5331

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_jl_steed_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1)
{
  
    int c0;
  

  
    size_t shape[1];
  

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_jl_steed_array,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,1,2,ain,aout};

  
    void *opt;
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt = &c0; //lmax

  

      if (c0<0) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be lmax>=0");
    }
    shape[0] = c0+1;


  
#line 63 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v1);
  
}

.bessel_Jn_array(nmin, nmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This routine computes the values of the regular cylindrical Bessel functions J_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • nmin (Integer)
  • nmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_Jn_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2)
{
  
    int c0;
  
    int c1;
  

  
#line 42 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_Jn_array,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,1,2,ain,aout};

  
#line 53 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    void *opt[2];
    
          c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //nmin

          c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //nmax

  

      if (c0<0 || c1<0 || c0>c1) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be nmin>=0 && nmax>=0 && nmin<=nmax");
    }
    shape[0] = c1-c0+1;


  
#line 63 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v2);
  
}

.bessel_kl_scaled_array(lmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This routine computes the values of the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel functions exp(x) k_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0 and x>0, storing the results in the array result_array. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Domain: lmax >= 0 Conditions: l=0,1,…,lmax Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • lmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

# File 'ext/numo/gsl/sf/gsl_sf.c', line 7106

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_kl_scaled_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1)
{
  
    int c0;
  

  
    size_t shape[1];
  

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_kl_scaled_array,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,1,2,ain,aout};

  
    void *opt;
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt = &c0; //lmax

  

      if (c0<0) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be lmax>=0");
    }
    shape[0] = c0+1;


  
#line 63 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v1);

.bessel_Kn_array(nmin, nmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This routine computes the values of the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel functions K_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array. The start of the range nmin must be positive or zero. The domain of the function is x>0. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Conditions: n=nmin,…,nmax Domain: x > 0.0, nmin>=0, nmax >= nmin Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • nmin (Integer)
  • nmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]



4152
4153
4154
4155
4156
4157
4158
4159
4160
4161
4162
4163
4164
4165
4166
4167
4168
4169
4170
4171
4172
4173
4174
4175
4176

4179
4180

4183
4184
4185
4186
4187
4188
4189
4190
4191
4192
 
# File 'ext/numo/gsl/sf/gsl_sf.c', line 4152

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_Kn_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2)
{
  
    int c0;
  
    int c1;
  

  
#line 42 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    size_t shape[1];
  

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_Kn_array,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,1,2,ain,aout};

  
#line 53 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    void *opt[2];
    
          c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //nmin

          c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //nmax

  

      if (c0<0 || c1<0 || c0>c1) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be nmin>=0 && nmax>=0 && nmin<=nmax");
    }
    shape[0] = c1-c0+1;


  
#line 63 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v2);
  
}

    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_Kn_scaled,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,1,1,ain,aout};

  
    void *opt;
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt = &c0; //n

  

  

  
#line 63 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v1);
  
}

.bessel_Kn_scaled_array(nmin, nmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This routine computes the values of the scaled irregular cylindrical Bessel functions exp(x) K_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array. The start of the range nmin must be positive or zero. The domain of the function is x>0. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Domain: x > 0.0, nmin >=0, nmax >= nmin Conditions: n=nmin,…,nmax Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • nmin (Integer)
  • nmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_Kn_scaled_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2)
{
  
    int c0;
  
    int c1;
  

  
#line 42 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    size_t shape[1];
  

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_Kn_scaled_array,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,1,2,ain,aout};

  
#line 53 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    void *opt[2];
    
          c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //nmin

          c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //nmax

  

      if (c0<0 || c1<0 || c0>c1) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be nmin>=0 && nmax>=0 && nmin<=nmax");
    }
    shape[0] = c1-c0+1;


  
#line 63 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v2);
  
}

.bessel_yl_array(lmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This routine computes the values of the irregular spherical Bessel functions y_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Domain: lmax >= 0 Conditions: l=0,1,…,lmax Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • lmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]



5920

5951
5952
 
# File 'ext/numo/gsl/sf/gsl_sf.c', line 5920

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_yl_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1)
{
  
    int c0;
  

  
    size_t shape[1];
  

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_yl_array,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,1,2,ain,aout};

  
    void *opt;
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt = &c0; //lmax

  

      if (c0<0) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be lmax>=0");
    }
    shape[0] = c0+1;


  
#line 63 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v1);
  
}

.bessel_Yn_array(nmin, nmax, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This routine computes the values of the irregular cylindrical Bessel functions Y_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array. The domain of the function is x>0. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • nmin (Integer)
  • nmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_Yn_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2)
{
  
    int c0;
  
    int c1;
  

  
#line 42 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    size_t shape[1];
  

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_Yn_array,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,1,2,ain,aout};

  
#line 53 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    void *opt[2];
    
          c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //nmin

          c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //nmax

  

      if (c0<0 || c1<0 || c0>c1) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be nmin>=0 && nmax>=0 && nmin<=nmax");
    }
    shape[0] = c1-c0+1;


  
#line 63 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v2);

.beta(a, b) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

These routines compute the Beta Function, B(a,b) = Gamma(a)Gamma(b)/Gamma(a+b) subject to a and b not being negative integers. exceptions: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW, GSL_EUNDRFLW

  • a (Numo::DFloat)
  • b (Numo::DFloat)

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

}

.beta_e(a, b) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

.beta_inc(a, b, x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

These routines compute the normalized incomplete Beta function I_x(a,b)=B_x(a,b)/B(a,b) where $B_x(a,b) = int_0^x t^a-1 (1-t)^b-1 dt$ B_x(a,b) = int_0^x t^@a-1@ (1-t)^@b-1@ dt for $0 le x le 1$ 0 <= x <= 1. For a > 0, b > 0 the value is computed using a continued fraction expansion. For all other values it is computed using the relation $I_x(a,b,x) = (1/a) x^a {}_2F_1(a,1-b,a+1,x)/B(a,b)$ I_x(a,b,x) = (1/a) x^a 2F1(a,1-b,a+1,x)/B(a,b).

Parameters:

  • a (Numo::DFloat)
  • b (Numo::DFloat)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return



19975
19976
19977
19978
19979

19981
19982
19983

19985

19989

{
  

  

#line 45 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"

    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_beta_inc,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,3,1,ain,aout};

}

For a > 0, b > 0 the value is computed using a continued fraction expansion. For all other values it is computed using the relation $I_x(a,b,x) = (1/a) x^a {}_2F_1(a,1-b,a+1,x)/B(a,b)$ I_x(a,b,x) = (1/a) x^a 2F1(a,1-b,a+1,x)/B(a,b).

.Chi(x) ⇒ Numo::DFloat

.cos_err_e(x, dx) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This routine computes the cosine of an angle x with an associated absolute error dx, $cos(x pm dx)$ cos(x pm dx). Note that this function is provided in the error-handling form only since its purpose is to compute the propagated error.

.coulomb_CL_array(Lmin, kmax, eta) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This function computes the Coulomb wave function normalization constant C_L(eta) for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax, Lmin > -1.

Parameters:

  • Lmin (Numo::DFloat)
  • kmax (Integer)
  • eta (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [cl[], return]

# File 'ext/numo/gsl/sf/gsl_sf.c', line 9478

static VALUE
numo_s_coulomb_CL_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2)
{
  
    int c1;
  

  
    size_t shape[1];
  

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[2] = {{cDF,0},{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_coulomb_CL_array,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,2,2,ain,aout};

  
    void *opt;
        c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt = &c1; //kmax

  

      if (c1<0) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be kmax>=0");
    }
    shape[0] = c1+1;


  
#line 63 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,2,v0,v2);
  
}

.coulomb_wave_F_array(L_min, kmax, eta, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This function computes the Coulomb wave function F_L(eta,x) for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax, storing the results in fc_array. In the case of overflow the exponent is stored in F_exponent.

  • L_min (Numo::DFloat)
  • kmax (Integer)
  • eta (Numo::DFloat)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

static VALUE
numo_s_coulomb_wave_F_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2,VALUE v3)
{
  
    int c1;
  

  
    size_t shape[1];
  

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[3] = {{cDF,0},{cDF,0},{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[3] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cDF,0},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_coulomb_wave_F_array,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,3,3,ain,aout};

  
    void *opt;
        c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt = &c1; //kmax

  

      if (c1<0) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be kmax>=0");
    }
    shape[0] = c1+1;

.coulomb_wave_FG_array(L_min, kmax, eta, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This function computes the functions F_L(eta,x), G_L(eta,x) for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax storing the results in fc_array and gc_array. In the case of overflow the exponents are stored in F_exponent and G_exponent.

  • kmax (Integer)
  • eta (Numo::DFloat)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

static VALUE
numo_s_coulomb_wave_FG_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2,VALUE v3)

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[3] = {{cDF,0},{cDF,0},{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[5] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cDF,1,shape},{cDF,0},{cDF,0},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_coulomb_wave_FG_array,NO_LOOP|NDF_EXTRACT,3,5,ain,aout};

        c1 = NUM2INT(v1);

.coulomb_wave_FG_e(eta, x, L_F, k) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This function computes the Coulomb wave functions F_L(eta,x), $G_L-k(eta,x)$ G_@L-k@(eta,x) and their derivatives F'_L(eta,x), $G'_L-k(eta,x)$ G'_@L-k@(eta,x) with respect to x. The parameters are restricted to L, L-k > -1/2, x > 0 and integer k. Note that L itself is not restricted to being an integer. The results are stored in the parameters F, G for the function values and Fp, Gp for the derivative values. If an overflow occurs, GSL_EOVRFLW is returned and scaling exponents are stored in the modifiable parameters exp_F, exp_G.

Parameters:

  • eta (Numo::DFloat)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)
  • L_F (Numo::DFloat)
  • k (Integer)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [F.val, F.err, Fp.val, Fp.err, G.val, G.err, Gp.val, Gp.err, exp_F, exp_G, return]

.coulomb_wave_FGp_array(L_min, kmax, eta, x) ⇒ [Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]

This function computes the functions F_L(eta,x), G_L(eta,x) and their derivatives F'_L(eta,x), G'_L(eta,x) for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax storing the results in fc_array, gc_array, fcp_array and gcp_array. In the case of overflow the exponents are stored in F_exponent and G_exponent.

  • kmax (Integer)
  • eta (Numo::DFloat)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)
